awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mass Extinction Ecological Response and Recovery in the Cretaceous/Paleogene Gulf Coastal Plain
awd_abstract_narration:
It is largely unknown how marine animals today will respond to current and future environmental change. This research is using the geologic record of a mass extinction event 66 million years ago as a natural laboratory to understand habitat loss and species survival during rapid environmental changes. The systematically collected paleo-environment and fossil data are the foundation of immersive, online 'Virtual Field Experiences' that engage students with the field collection and lab processing methods of Earth Sciences research. Online experiences and lesson plans aligned with Next Generation Science Standards are broadly available through well-known online portals and disseminated to teachers in the Gulf Coast states.

Periods of extreme, rapid environmental change in Earth history are informative for predicting current and future survivorship in response to changing climate. These events also provide the opportunity to test hypotheses on macroevolutionary pattern and process. This project involves compiling species occurrences and paleoenvironments across the end-Cretaceous mass extinction (~66 Ma) in the U.S. Gulf Coastal Plain. Topics of investigation include (1) the impact of available suitable habitat and habitat continuity on extinction potential; (2) the impact of extreme environmental change on patterns of niche stability within species, and phylogenetic niche conservation within clades; and (3) the influence of extreme environmental change on macroecological shifts in body size and physiological flexibility. This research supports three female early-career PIs, and graduate and undergraduate students at five institutions (two of which serve non-traditional, minority-majority student populations) are trained in field, laboratory, and analytical Earth Science. Two Virtual Field Experiences with high school-level lesson plans will emphasize hypothesis testing and the significance of extinction events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary (KPB, ~66 million years ago) is marked by a drastic extinction of ~70% of species globally, including all non-avian dinosaurs. This project explored how that extinction event played out in the Gulf Coastal Plain region in marine mollusks. While some co-investigators focused on compiling and constructing databases of fossil occurrences to track which species went extinct where and when, researchers at University of Michigan focused on reconstructing ocean conditions in this period of the ancient past. We used isotopic methods (clumped isotope paleothermometry) to determine the water temperature in which fossil mollusk shells lived at multiple sites across the Gulf Coastal Plain (Texas, Arkansas, Alabama, Mississippi, and Georgia), at time periods both before and after the KPB.

 

We found that Gulf waters were a few degrees Celsius warmer in the latest Cretaceous and earliest Paleogene than they are today. This is consistent with the Cretaceous being a period of elevated atmospheric CO2 and global warmth. We found that temperatures before and after the boundary were very stable. This possibly indicates that while the Chicxulub meteorite impact had a dramatic effect on marine life, disappearances of specific organisms were not likely linked to the disappearance of suitable habitats for them to live in, as after the initial perturbations subsided, the same habitats were present during the longer-term recovery phase.

 

We also used another calculated quantity (d18Osw) to estimate salinity conditions in the Gulf and found those to also be similar to today. Across the boundary, d18Osw values were stable, or slightly increasing (possibly indicating increasing salinity), in support of the overall stable conditions on the thousand to million year timescales around this punctuating event.

 

Overall, this project dramatically increased the spatial and temporal coverage of paleo-temperature data and paleo-salinity estimates within the Gulf Coastal Plain across the Cretaceous Paleogene boundary. These oceanographic datasets will be useful for future comparisons to faunal records.

 

The University of Michigan portion of this collaborative project supported an early career female PI, 1 part time graduate and 4 undergraduate students. This award supported connections between the UMich team and researchers at 6 other institutions with a variety of topics of expertise, creating a supportive research and mentor-mentee network for students on the team. Outreach programming at a local Nature School exposed children to fossils and the tools and techniques we use to collect them in a hands-on activity. UM researchers contributed to the development of a virtual field experience designed for general classroom use.
